option.name: description
option.value:
As we’re embracing Information Age, data becomes so abundant that processing it is no easy business. Names and numbers: how does one make sense of them? In this project, you will be writing a program that processes textual and numeric data and sorts it nicely. Make it a truly talented program: enable it to determine the biggest or most frequent pieces of data and perform necessary calculations. Data is waiting to be sorted!

Learn more at https://hyperskill.org/projects/45

option.name: description
option.value: As we’re embracing Information Age, data becomes so abundant that processing it is no easy business. Names and numbers: how does one make sense of them? In this project, you will be writing a program that processes textual and numeric data and sorts it nicely. Make it a truly talented program: enable it to determine the biggest or most frequent pieces of data and perform necessary calculations. Data is waiting to be sorted!

option.name: descriptionText
option.value:
Description

This project is about sorting different data. Numbers, words, lines.

In the first stage, let's stick to integers only. The program should read integers from the console. Note, that every line of input can contain multiple numbers - and these numbers can be separated not only by a single space but let's say 20 spaces. 

Your program should process every line the user inputs. To end the input, the user should type Ctrl+D.

Notice that if you run your program and try to manually type numbers you realize that this process will go on infinitely. And by pressing Ctrl+D you say to the program that you won't type any more symbols to the standard input. And in this case, scanner.hasNext... will return false. So, you don't need to check specifically for Ctrl+D to be typed.

After the end of the input, your program should output three things:

  1. The number of numbers in the input  (X)
  2. The greatest number in the input (Y)
  3. How many times this greatest number occurs in the input (Z)

You should paste these numbers in the following template:

Total numbers: X.
The greatest number: Y (Z time(s)).

Input example

1 -2   33 4
42
1                 1

Output example

Total numbers: 7.
The greatest number: 42 (1 time(s)).

option.name: text
text
text
descriptionText
option.value:
Description

In this stage, you should implement command-line arguments parsing. Parse the -dataType argument and it's following type. The type can be only long, line or word. If the argument is not provided, you should assume that -dataType argument is word.

After that, you must treat all the user inputs as numbers, words or lines depending on command-line argument that was passed to the program.

If the argument is word, the program should separate all the user input into words separated by spaces. You should compare words by length and in case two words have the same length - lexicographically.

If the argument is line, the program should separate all the user input into lines. You should compare two lines by length and in case two lines have the same length - lexicographically, like the words compared. Notice that you should print the longest line on a separate line so you end up with 4 lines being printed, not 2. You can see this in the examples.

You should also add the percentage of occurrence of the found word among all words (words, integers or lines).

By the way, in the case of lines, you should print the longest line on a separate line, but words and numbers should be printed on the same line as percentages. You can see this behavior in the examples.

Run configuration examples

java SortingTool -dataType long

java SortingTool -dataType line

java SortingTool -dataType word

Input example

1 -2   333 4
42
1                 1

Output example for words

Total words: 7.
The longest word: 333 (1 time(s), 14%).

Output example for lines

Total lines: 3.
The longest line:
1                 1
(1 time(s), 33%).

Output example for integers 

Total numbers: 7.
The greatest number: 333 (1 time(s), 14%).

option.name: text
text
text
descriptionText
option.value:
Description

In this stage, you should parse -sortIntegers argument. This argument should indicate that the numbers that user input should be sorted. 

If the -sortIntegers argument is presented, you should ignore other arguments, otherwise, the behavior of the program should be the same as in the previous stage.

After processing user data, print Sorted data: and then print all integers sorted in ascending order.

Run configuration examples

java SortingTool -sortIntegers

Input example

1 -2   33 4
42
1                 1

Output example (for sorting task)

Total numbers: 7.
Sorted data: -2 1 1 1 4 33 42

option.name: text
text
text
descriptionText
option.value:
Description

In this stage, you should implement sorting by count. The result should be pairs like (count, dataEntry) sorted by count.

Remove parsing of the -sortIntegers argument. Instead of this argument add another - named -sortingType.  This argument can be followed by natural or byCount sorting types. If -sortingType is not presented among argument list then consider natural to be the default sorting type.

If -dataType is word or line, use String.compareTo(String) method to compare strings in sorting.

To sum up, your program should support two sorting methods now and work with all types of data.

How-to

You can use the following algorithm:

  1. Sort data entries into List<DataType> sortedDataEntries.
  2. Iterate over it and create Map<DataType, Integer> dataEntryToCount.
  3. Iterate over it and create List<Integer> counts.
  4. Sort it into List<Integer> sortedCounts and remove duplicates in it.
  5. Iterate over dataEntryToCount and create Map<Integer, Set<DataEntry>> countToDataEntries.
  6. Now iterate over sortedCounts and print all data entries from countToDataEntries.get(count).

Or you can use sorting with comparator to skip the last four actions.

Run configuration examples

java SortingTool -sortingType natural -dataType long

java SortingTool -dataType word -sortingType byCount

Input example

1 -2   33 4
42
1                 1

Output example for sorting longs by count

Total numbers: 7.
-2: 1 time(s), 14%
4: 1 time(s), 14%
33: 1 time(s), 14%
42: 1 time(s), 14%
1: 3 time(s), 43%

option.name: text
text
text
descriptionText
option.value:
Description

What if someone runs your program like this: java SortingTool -sortingType? The value of the -sortingType argument is missing!

And what if -dataType argument is long but there are words in the input text?

What if there are unknown arguments?

Let's handle these errors. 

In summary, for this stage, implement error messages when the input is wrong.

 

Run configuration example

java SortingTool -sortingType

Output example

No sorting type defined!

 

Run configuration example

java SortingTool -dataType

Output example

No data type defined!

 

Run configuration example

java SortingTool -dataType long -sortingType natural -abc -def

Input example

a 2 -42

Output example

"-abc" isn't a valid parameter. It's skipped.
"-def" isn't a valid parameter. It's skipped.
"a" isn't a long. It's skipped.
Total numbers: 7.
Sorted data: -42 2

option.name: text
text
text
text
text
descriptionText
option.value:
Description

Sometimes it's useful to read data from a file and write the result to another file.

Implement parsing of two more arguments: -inputFile and -outputFile.
If the -inputFile argument is provided, read input data from the file with the given name.
If the -outputFile argument is provided, only print info messages to the console (like errors parsing arguments).
Print the results to the file.

Run configuration examples

java SortingTool -sortingType byCount -inputFile input.txt
java SortingTool -sortingType byCount -inputFile data.dat -outputFile out.txt

Creating a set Open on Hyperskill

Create TreeSet by name set in any way known to you and fill it with the following three strings "Gamma", "Alpha", "Omega" .

The code for displaying the set is already written.


Sample Input:

Sample Output:
[Alpha, Gamma, Omega]


Memory limit: 256 Mb
Time limit: 5s


Show topic summary

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Removing duplicates and sorting Open on Hyperskill

Write a program that reads a sequence of strings from the standard input and displays them in a lexicographic order without duplicates.

Try to write your solution using a set.

Input data format

The first line contains the size of a string sequence. Next lines contain strings.

Output data format

A sorted sequence of strings without duplicates. Each string must be in a new line.


Sample Input:
6
postgres
sqlite
oracle
mongodb
postgres
mssql
Sample Output:
mongodb
mssql
oracle
postgres
sqlite

Sample Input:
5
1
2
2
11
20
Sample Output:
1
11
2
20


Memory limit: 256 Mb
Time limit: 5s


Show topic summary

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Symmetric difference Open on Hyperskill

Implement a method for finding the symmetric difference of two given sets. Elements in the resulting set can be in any order.

An example

The symmetric difference of two sets {1, 2, 3} and {0, 1, 2} is {0, 3}


Sample Input:
1 2 3
0 1 2

Sample Output:
0 3


Memory limit: 256 Mb
Time limit: 5s


Show topic summary

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Displaying pairs Open on Hyperskill

The map is given. Output each its key-value pair in the loop with a new line.

Each line must be in form of key=value (for example, Gamma=3)

Sample Input:

Sample Output:
Alpha=1
Gamma=3
Omega=24


Memory limit: 256 Mb
Time limit: 5s


Show topic summary

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Processing maps - 2 Open on Hyperskill

Modify and return the given map as follows:
  • if the first key % 2 != 0 return sub-map from First Key inclusive to FirstKey+4 inclusive in descending order
  • else return sub-map from LastKey-4 inclusive to the Last Key inclusive in descending order

Sample Input:
1:one 2:two 3:three 4:four 5:five 6:six 7:seven
Sample Output:
5 : five
4 : four
3 : three
2 : two
1 : one

Sample Input:
2:two 4:four 6:six 8:eight 10:ten 12:twelve 14:fourteen
Sample Output:
14 : fourteen
12 : twelve
10 : ten


Memory limit: 256 Mb
Time limit: 5s


Show topic summary

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Multiset Open on Hyperskill

A multiset is a generalization of the concept of a set. Unlike sets, it can store duplicate elements. The number of instances of an element is the multiplicity.

For example, given the following multiset:

{a, a, b, b, b, c}

The multiplicity of a is 2, the multiplicity of b is 3, the multiplicity of c is 1. If a multiset does not have an element, the multiplicity of it is 0.

Write an implementation of the provided generic interface Multiset. The template for your generic class named HashMultiset is given as well. You should implement all methods of the class, according to its interface. You also can add additional methods for helping.

Read the given interface to understand the common multiset operations (add, remove, union, intersection and so one).

Do not forget to test your class. If your implementation is not correct, the testing system gives you a hint throwing an exception with a text, like: 

Exception in thread "main" java.lang.AssertionError: size() returned an incorrect result

When you pass your solution to the submit form, do not remove the interface and do not make it and the class public.



Memory limit: 256 Mb
Time limit: 5s


Show topic summary

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Spell checker Open on Hyperskill

The simplest spell checker is based on a list of known words. Every word in the checked text is searched for in this list and, if such a word was not found, it is marked as erroneous.

Write this spell checker.

The first line of the input contains \( d \) – number of records in the list of known word. Next go \( d \) lines contain one known word per line, next — the number \( l \) of lines of the text, after which — \( l \) lines of the text.

Write a program that outputs those words from the text, which are not found in the dictionary (i.e. erroneous). Your spell checker should be case insensitive. The words are entered in an arbitrary order. Words, which are not found in the dictionary, should not be duplicated in the output.


Sample Input:
3
a
bb
cCc
2
a bb aab aba ccc
c bb aaa
Sample Output:
c
aab
aaa
aba


Memory limit: 256 Mb
Time limit: 5s


Show topic summary

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Convert vehicles and cars to string Open on Hyperskill

Given two classes Vehicle and Car. The second class extends the first one.

Override toString in both classes to return string representation of vehicles and cars.

If an object is Vehicle, the overridden method toString must return something like: 

Vehicle{licensePlate=ABC123}

If an object is Car, the overridden method toString must return something like: 

Car{licensePlate=ABC123,numberOfSeats=4}


Memory limit: 256 Mb
Time limit: 5s


Show topic summary

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Account Open on Hyperskill

There is a class named Account. It includes three fields: id, code and balance.

Override the method toString() in this class. The method should return a string representation of the account instance.

Do not make the class public.

Example

Account{id=10, code='123-456-789', balance=2000}


Memory limit: 256 Mb
Time limit: 5s


Show topic summary

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Time as a string Open on Hyperskill

Given a class named Time. It has three int fields: hours, minutes and seconds. Override the method toString in the class to return a string representation of an object.

The overridden method must return a string hours, minutes and seconds separated by colons. If a number contains only a single digit, add a zero first.

Here are some examples: "23:59:59", "11:08:05", "01:01:01".


Memory limit: 256 Mb
Time limit: 5s


Show topic summary

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Who is who Open on Hyperskill

Given a class hierarchy consisting of three classes. The base class is Employee. The first subclass is Developer, the second subclass is DataAnalyst.

Implement a method determineWhoIsWho. The method takes an array of employees. Each element belongs to one of listed classes. The method should output the type (DEV, EMP or DA) of each element in a new line.

Use the provided template for your method.

Output example

DEV
EMP
DA


Memory limit: 256 Mb
Time limit: 5s

descriptionText

Sort out the classes Open on Hyperskill

Given 4 classes - Shape, Polygon, Square, Circle.

Classes Polygon and Circle both extends class Shape, class Square extends class Polygon.

You need to implement a method that should take Shape array and add every element to one of the provided Lists based on their class.


Sample Input:
Solve the task!
Sample Output:
Good job!


Memory limit: 256 Mb
Time limit: 5s


Show topic summary

option.name: text
descriptionText
option.value:
Sum of the areas Open on Hyperskill

Given this classes: 
class Shape {}
class Square extends Shape {
    private int side;
    public int getSide() {
        return side;
    }
    public void setSide(int side) {
        this.side = side;
    }
}
class Rectangle extends Shape {
    private int width, height;
    public int getWidth() {
        return width;
    }
    public void setWidth(int width) {
        this.width = width;
    }
    public int getHeight() {
        return height;
    }
    public void setHeight(int height) {
        this.height = height;
    }
}
Unfortunately, the author of this classes forgot to add getArea() method to this classes. And now you need to implement a method that calculates a sum of areas of the Shape array. If some elements are instances of class Shape then their area equals 0.

Sample Input:
4
Shape
Square 10
Square 20
Rectangle 20 3
Sample Output:
560


Memory limit: 256 Mb
Time limit: 5s


Show topic summary
